title: process-models-workshop
text: 1 Introduction

title: process-models-workshop
text:
1.1 Workshop outline



Time
Day 1
Day 2




9-9:30
Introductions and workshop overview
Review of previous days topics


9:30-10:30
Theory/conceptual motivation for process models
Overview of simulation-based machine learning & Intro to the MESS model


10:30-10:45
Coffee Break
Coffee Break


10:45-12
Coding exercise: A simple neutral model of biodiversity
Simulation exercise: Using MESS to develop and test theoretical intuition


12-1
Lunch Break
Lunch Break


1-2:30
Simulation Exercise: Exploring neutral model behavior
Simulation based machine learning inference (Classification)


2:30-2:45
Coffee Break
Coffee Break


2:45-4:00
Intro to machine learning inference with neutral simulations
Simulation based machine learning inference (Regression) & Wrap-up



This is a quarto book project for creating materials for the second half of the MDBD workshop.
There is a list of planned sections in the “List of sections” chapter.
To add a new section, start from the “Template section”. Open template_section.qmd, save-as, and populate it; then add it to the list of sections in _quarto.yml.
To update the Pages site, run quarto render from a local terminal. This will render the files to the docs directory. Then push, and GitHub pages will serve the site from docs.

title: 2  Theory and motivation of process modeling
text:
2.1 Key questions

What is a process modeling approach?
What kinds of questions can process models explore (that other methods cannot)?
What are the limitations or constraints of process modeling?

title: 2  Theory and motivation of process modeling
text:
2.2 Lesson objectives
After this lesson, learners should be able to…

Describe what defines a process model.
Evaluate the advantages and limitations of a process modeling approach.
Generate questions in ecology and evolution that could be addressed using process modeling.

title: 2  Theory and motivation of process modeling

List planned activities for this section of the workshop. Examples could include (but not limited to) lectures, live-coding demos, breakout sessions, group discussions, etc.

title: 5  Simulation-based machine learning inference
text:
5.1 Key questions

What kinds of empirical data can we leverage using process modeling?
How can we infer process from empirical data using simulation models?
What are the challenges associated with this and how do we resolve them?

title: 5  Simulation-based machine learning inference
text:
5.2 Lesson objectives
After this lesson, learners should be able to…

Articulate ways in which empirical data could be elucdiated using sim models
Describe the conceptual framework for going data-to-process
Describe the many-to-one/model identifiability problems and how to break them

title: 5  Simulation-based machine learning inference
text:
5.3 Planned exercises
Andy’s neutral theory / random forest page

Lecture: Random Forest for Machine Learning Inference
Lecture: How does machine learning work with RoLE simulations?

title: 6  Introduction to the MESS Model
text: 7 Getting started: roleR

title: 6  Introduction to the MESS Model
text:
6.1 Key questions

What is the MESS Model?
What are some of the possible applications of the RoLE Model?
How do I learn more?

title: 6  Introduction to the MESS Model
text:
6.2 Lesson objectives
After this lesson, learners should be able to…

Situate RoLE in the wider process modeling state space.
Describe the (high-level) concept for RoLE.
Formulate scientific questions and decide if/how RoLE can be used to explore them.

title: 6  Introduction to the MESS Model
text:
6.3 Planned exercises

Lecture: Process-based modeling with the Rules of Life Engine (RoLE) Model
Hands-on: Exploring RoLE model behavior with the RoLE-Shiny app

title: 6  Introduction to the MESS Model
text:
7.1 Key questions

How do I set up and run a RoLE model in R?
What are the inputs and outputs of a RoLE model?
What happens when a RoLE model runs?
How do I access and visualize the results of a RoLE simulation?
How can I store the outputs of a RoLE model?

title: 6  Introduction to the MESS Model
text:
7.2 Lesson objectives
After this lesson, learners should be able to…

Describe the structure of a RoLE model.
Describe the rules of a RoLE simulation.
Describe the outputs of a RoLE model and what they say about the system.
Use roleR to run a basic RoLE model.
Extract summary statistics from a RolE model, plot them, and relate the visuals to ecological/evolutionary processes.
Save RoLE models to disk.

title: 6  Introduction to the MESS Model
text:
7.3 Planned exercises

Installation
TL;DR Run your first simulations
Getting started with roleR
Creating a roleParams object and setting model parameters
Run simulations using the new roleParams
Inspect the output of the simulation runs
Setting prior ranges on parameters
Experimentation time (set a challenge and report back?)


7.3.1 Installing roleR

You do not need to install roleR for this workshop, rather this is here for completeness and future information should you wish to install RoLE on your home cluster.

roleR is currently installed directly from the github repository using the remotes::github_install() function.
> install.packages("remotes")
> library(remotes)
> remotes::install_github('role-model/roleR')

Synthesize the outcomes

title: 8  Machine learning inference with MESS simulations
text:
8.1 Key questions

How do I perform a process-inference using RoLE simulations in R?

title: 8  Machine learning inference with MESS simulations
text:
8.2 Lesson objectives
After this lesson, learners should be able to…

Use RoLE simulations and RandomForest ML (w/ tidymodels) to perform inference
Interpret results in terms of story
Brainstorm applications to real data

title: 8  Machine learning inference with MESS simulations
text:
8.3 Planned exercises

Lecture: How does machine learning work with RoLE simulations?


Create and parameterize a new RoLE Experiment
Run RoLE model simulations
ML assembly model classification
ML parameter estimation
Posterior predictive simulations (if time)
Free time to experiment with other example datasets


8.3.1 Create a new RoLE Experiment

8.3.1.1 Create a new roleParams(), modifying a few default values
These are all the parameters of the model. The defaults are chosen to reflect a typical oceanic island arthropod community. Don’t worry at this point about all the parameters, lets focus for now on the degree of neutrality (neut_delta), the size of the local community (individuals_local), and the rate of migration from the metacommunity to the local community (dispersal_prob). We will set parameter ranges for these, and each simulation will sample a random value from this range. In a new cell use the we’ll create some new roleParams objects to reflect neutral, competition, and environmental filtering assembly models.
p_neutral <- roleParams()
p_comp <- roleParams()
p_filt <- roleParams()


8.3.1.2 Run the role experiment encapsulating these different models
Now we can run a bunch of simulations given our new parameterization using the runRole() method. runRole takes one argument (nsims) which indicates the number of independent community assembly realizations to perform.
exp <- roleExperiment(list(p_neutral, p_comp, p_filt))
exp <- runRole(exp)


8.3.1.3 Download the pre-baked simulations
Since it can take quite some time to run a number of simulations sufficient for model selection and parameter estimation we will use a suite of pre-baked simulations generated ahead of time. Go to the terminal tab in Rstudio and fetch them with wget from the workshop site:
\# FIXME
# Make sure you're in the role-workshop directory
cd ~/role-workshop
wget https://compphylo.github.io/Oslo2019/MESS_files/MESS_simulations/SIMOUT.txt
wc -l SIMOUT.txt
100%[======================================>] 14,234,338  50.0M/s   in 0.3s
2019-08-11 01:25:27 (50.0 MB/s) - "SIMOUT.txt.1" saved [14234338/14234338]
24440 SIMOUT.txt






Note



The wc command counts the number of lines if you pass it the -l flag. You can see this series of ~25k simulations is about 14MB.





8.3.2 ML assembly model classification
The first step is now to assess the model of community assembly that best fits the data. The three models are neutral, in which all individuals are ecologically equivalent; competition, in which species have traits, and differential survival probability is weighted by distance of traits from the trait mean in the local community (closer to the trait mean == higher probability of death); and filtering, in which there is an environmental optimum, and proximity of trait values to this optimum is positively correlated with survival probability.
Basically we want to know, are individuals in the local community ecologically equivalent, and if not are they interacting more with each other or more with the local environment.

8.3.2.1 Train the ML classifier


8.3.2.2 Plot confusion matrix


8.3.2.3 Perform classification of empirical data and view results



8.3.3 ML parameter estimation
Now that we have identified the neutral model as the most probable, we can estimate parameters of the emipirical data given this model. Essentially, we are asking the question “What are the parameters of the model that generate summary statistics most similar to those of the empirical data?”

8.3.3.1 Train the ML regressor


8.3.3.2 Plot cross-validation results


8.3.3.3 Perform regression to predict dispersal_prob of empirical data and view results
